FX

FOREX: DXY stronger ahead of FOMC Minutes

The USD was stronger across the board as it attempts to mount a recovery from the multi-year lows hit late last week, ahead of Wednesday’s FOMC minutes release. GBP was one of the better performers after a Business Insider article suggested the European Parliament was preparing to deliver a report that would call for increased flexibility in future relationship talks with the UK. The TRY tumbled after reports that Turkish forces had launched airstrikes in Syria.

COMMODITIES

CRUDE: WTI futures settle 22 cents higher at $61.90 per barrel; Brent futures settle 42 cents lower at $65.25 per barrel

The WTI Brent crude spread narrowed today as the US benchmark held onto minor gains while the Brent fell on the stronger USD. Some had pointed to a private inventory report which showed another decline in inventories at the Cushing hub in Oklahoma behind the gains for WTI, ahead of the API inventory report (delayed until Wednesday after Presidents’ Day).

UAE Energy Minister stated he expects solid commitments to OPEC cuts this year, adding that OPEC is considering the logic of a 5 year average target.


GEOPOLITICAL

Reports of Turkish artillery firing warning shots on pro-Syrian groups. Of note, this was after earlier reports of Turkish jets bombing an area where pro-Syrian convoys entered.  This was actually warning shots.


MARKET RECAP

EQUITIES: SPX -0.6% at 2715, DJI -1.0% at 24962, NDX +0.1% at  6780

Top sectors: IT +0.3%, Financials -0.2%, Consumer Discretionary -0.3%

Bottom sectors: Consumer Staples -2.3%, Telecom -1.7%, Utilities -1.3%

US equity markets were lower with the Dow Jones Industrial Average tumbling after Walmart’s outlook disappointed markets. The retail giant fell as much as 10% and also dragged down some of its peers, including Kroger who fells over 4%. On the other hand, Amazon’s shares jumped 2% as Walmart’s challenge falters and after the company announced perks for users of Amazon Prime credit cards. 

TREASURIES:  US T-Note futures (March 2018) settle down 3 ticks at 120-15+

US treasuries fell on Tuesday as markets attempt to absorb the mammoth US supply this week. The Treasury sold a total of USD 151bln of bills and USD 28bln worth of 2-year notes on Tuesday, ahead of 5-year note and 2-year FRN auctions on Wednesday and a 7-year auction on Thursday. Nevertheless, the 2-year sale seemed to go OK as the yield stopped through the WI at the bidding deadline, although demand – measured by the B/C – declined from its multi-year high in January.

FX Daily Wrap: Dollar recovery derailed by latest Russian probe
content: The DXY edged a little closer to reclaiming another milestone on its ongoing recovery from 88.250 approximate lows, but was thwarted on its advance towards 90.000 by latest charges by US Special Council Mueller against a Russian official. Usd/Jpy eclipsed the nearest upside chart resistance level at 107.32 (last year’s high) before retreating back to just above the 107.00 level, while Eur/Usd breached more interim supports under 1.2350, but stopped just a pip short of a key Fib at 1.2319. Cable revisited the lower end of its 1.3930-1.4015 broad range, but recovered well after earlier reports that EU Parliament would back privileged single market access for the UK post-Brexit. Usd/Cad (belatedly) surpassed 1.2610 resistance and its 100 DMA at 1.2623 in wake of much weaker than forecast Canadian wholesale trade data, but will be eyeing tier 1 releases later in the week for more independent impetus. Aud/Usd failed to regain 0.7900 after neutral RBA minutes, with the focus now on wages that have been sluggish, while Nzd/Usd bounced off strong tech support around 0.7338 ahead of the RBNZ’s annual review (one of acting head Spencer’s final official appointments), with no real reaction to flattish GDT auction prices. Elsewhere, Eur/Sek rallied sharply on the back of weak Swedish inflation data, from session lows of 9.9050 to just short of 9.9900 and with early February peaks around 10.000 the obvious draw. In the EM region, Usd/Try jumped on wire news of an escalation in the Turkey-Syria conflict, to 3.8000+ from sub-3.7600 at one stage.

FIXED AND FX LATEST: bonds and Usd firmer ahead of the Wall Street open
content: With US equity futures still pointing to a weaker return from the long holiday weekend, core debt and the Dollar benefited from another round of buying before the latter was undermined by latest Russia probe headlines. Bunds and Gilts have now been up to 158.55 and 121.39 respectively (+28 and +26 ticks), while Usd/Jpy knee-jerked above the 107.32 (2017 peak and near term resistance) before retreating amidst what looks like a more traditional risk-averse move.

DJIA

Apple (AAPL) – The tech giant’s iPhone X is losing out to Chinese devices in Asia due to its high price. Separately, Samsung will reportedly cut its output of OLED panels as a response to weak demand and production cuts of the iPhone X. (WSJ / CNBC)

General Electric (GE) – The tech giant is exploring a sale of its industrial gas engine unit which reportedly may be worth up to USD 2bln. (Newswires)

Intel (INTC) – The chipmakers board member David Pottruck is to retire at the end of his current term at the annual stockholders meeting in 2018. (Newswires)

S&P500

AbbVie (ABBV) – The co. and Voyager Therapeutics (VYGR) announced a global strategic collaboration to develop and commercialise antibodies directed against tau for the treatment of Alzheimer’s. (Newswires)

Arconic (ARNC) – The co. board size has decreased to 13 from 14 as Julie Richardson has decided to resign. (Newswires)

AT&T (T) / Time Warner (TWX) – The US DoJ has asked a federal judge to not allow AT&T’s defence to include a claim that the Trump administration improperly challenged the deal. (Newswires)

Cardinal Health (CAH) – Kentucky’s Attorney General filed a lawsuit against the drug distributor claiming it has contributed to the opioid epidemic by failing stop or report suspiciously large or orders by pharmacies of prescription painkillers. (Newswires)   

Domino’s Pizza (DPZ) – Restaurant Brands (QSR) is considering a bid for the pizza chain. (Brazil Journal)

General Mills (GIS) – Forecasts organic net sales at the high end of prior range and raises its FY18 EPS forecast to 3-4% from 1-2% growth. (Newswires)

General Motors (GM) – The automaker has offered a USD 2.2bln debt for equity swap for Seoul’s financial support. This comes after the announcement that it would be shutting one of its four South Korean plants and would decide on the future of the other 3 soon. (Newswires)

General Motors (GM) – The automakers Chevy Bolt sales have been boosted by delays from Tesla’s (TSLA) model 3. (Newswires)

Gun Names (AOBC, RGR) – US President Trump is open to stricter background checks regarding gun purchases. (White House)

Huntington Ingalls (HII) – The co, has been awarded a USD 1.43bln government contract modification. (Newswires)

Mattel (MAT) – The toy maker is to relaunch its Polly Pocket after 30 years of its original launch. (Newswires)

Philip Morris (PM) – The tobacco co. and Scuderia Ferrari (RACE) have extended their partnership until 2021, carrying on the focus vision of a smoke free world. (Newswires)

Yum Brands! (YUM) – The co.’s KFC restaurants in the UK have been facing chicken shortages due to logistics problems with its delivery partner DHL, some restaurants were temporarily closed. (CNBC)

 

NASDAQ 100

21st Century Fox (FOXA) – The entertainment co. has strengthened its commitment on Sky News independence, as it said it would maintain a Sky branded news service for 10 years if it can purchase the UK Broadcaster. Further, Fox News is planning a new streaming service called Fox Nation. (Sky News)

Biogen (BIIB) – The co. CEO announced investors had over reacted to news that it was adding patients to its Alzheimer’s drug trial, stating the possible expansion of the patient base had been in place before the trial began. (Newswires)

Facebook (FB) – The social media giant is increasing its security efforts following the US election interference. Axios report it is increasing its security team size by 10,000 to 20,000 this year. (Newswires / Axios)

Gilead (GILD) – A US Judge has dismissed a jury’s verdict requiring the co. to pay USD 2.54bln because its hepatitis C drugs infringed a patent held by Merck (MRK). (Newswires)

Mylan (MYL) – The pharmaceutical co. announced it received tentative approval from FDA for its New Drug Application for Dolutegravir. (Newswires)

Qualcomm (QCOM) / Broadcom (AVGO) – Broadcom announced the Institutional Shareholder Services has recommended Qualcomm stockholders vote for four of Broadcom’s independent director nominees. (Newswires)

Qualcomm (QCOM) / NXP Semiconductors (NXPI) – Qualcomm has raised its bid for NXP Semiconductors to USD 44bln (USD 127.50/shr) according to WSJ. Further, SunTrust report that the only remaining hurdle regarding the acquisition is receiving approval from China. (WSJ)

 

OTHER NEWS

Aimmune (AIMT) – The therapeutics co. phase 3 trial of a peanut allergy study met its primary endpoint. Also, of note for DBV Technologies. (DBVT). (Newswires)

Alibaba (BABA) – The online Chinese retail giant and Tencent are on a retain investment binge, having spent USD 10bln on retail focused deals since the beginning of 2017 and are forcing customers to choose sides during a battle for shoppers’ digital wallets. (Newswires)

Cars.com (CARS) – Activist investor Starboard has raised its stake in the co. to 9.9% from 7%. (Newswires)

Pandora (P) – The music streaming service announced it has built a premium marketplace for advertisers. (Newswires)

PREVIEW: Fonterra GDT Dairy Auction - futures indicate stagnation after 3 consecutive price rises (and an especially big increase in early February)
content:
The most recent auction saw the headline GDT price index rise by 5.9% to USD 3,646, while whole milk powder prices rose by 7.6% to USD 3,226.

 

Although dairy prices have been inflated by drought factors for several weeks since the start of 2018, the latest big jump in the headline index, and more so whole milk powder suggests that some moderation is likely this time round as the overall steady trend remains intact. Indeed, ASB and CBA both note that futures indicate no change in prices, with the WMP contract only up 1% and likely overstating underlying trends as usual.  

 

Although there is no set time for release, the last auction results on 16th January were released around 14:35GMT.

subject: DAILY US OPENING NEWS:  European equities have trimmed initial gains (Eurostoxx 50 flat) to trade with little in the way of firm direction ahead of the US return to market
content:
20th February 2018

  • European equities have trimmed initial gains (Eurostoxx 50 flat) to trade with little in the way of firm direction ahead of the US return to market
  • EU Parliament is to call for Britain to have privileged single market access after Brexit, according to Business Insider
  • Looking ahead, highlights include US supply

ASIA-PAC

Equity markets are somewhat fragile, with major Asian bourses off to a weaker start. US markets were closed for President’s day and as such, Asian participants took the cue from European equities which slipped in yesterday’s session. In Australia, the ASX 200 (flat) has come under pressure from material and financial names, with many of the large banks reversing the prior days gains. Over in Japan, the Nikkei (-1.0%) had tripped through 22,000 amid softness in tech names. The Hang Seng (-0.8%) reopened for the first time since last week, however initial gains had been short-lived, with the index conforming to the sombre tone.

JGBs are flat in thin-trade, March futures contract down 2 ticks and hovering near yesterday’s levels. USTs off by 6+ ticks with yields continuing to pick up, 2yr yields now at the highest since Sep’08 after hitting 2.22%, while the US curve is also flattening this morning.

The RBA meeting minutes failed to provide any fireworks with the central bank sticking with its neutral tone. As such, AUD had been largely unmoved post the release of the minutes and instead focus will fall on the wage price index due out tomorrow. RBA February minutes states that low rates are helping reduce unemployment and lift inflation, additionally rising AUD would impede pickup in economic growth and inflation, however AUD TWI is still within narrow range of past couple of years. (Newswires)

EU/UK/US

EU Parliament is to call for Britain to have privileged single market access after Brexit. (Business Insider)

The UK is said to have a secret plan to withhold Brexit payments if the EU refuses to provide the UK with a desirable trade deal. (Newswires) Elsewhere, according to a letter seen last week, Netherlands government has linked its decision to activate hard Brexit plan amid a lack of clarity from the UK. (Sky)

German Economy Minister says the EU will respond appropriately if the US puts a tariff on European steel imports. (Newswires)

German ZEW Economic Sentiment (Feb) 17.8 vs. Exp. 16.5 (Prev. 20.4)

German ZEW Current Conditions (Feb) 92.3 vs. Exp. 93.9 (Prev. 95.2)

CENTAL BANKS

Spain’s Economy Minister de Guindos was confirmed as the nominee by the Eurogroup for the ECB Vice-President role. (Newswires)

ECB's Hansson (hawk) says he's not interested in becoming ECB President. (Newswires)

EQUITIES

European equities have trimmed initial gains (Eurostoxx 50 flat) to trade with little in the way of firm direction ahead of the US return to market. The FSTE 100 modestly lags its peers (-0.4%) after disappointing earnings from index heavyweights HSBC (-4%) and BHP Billiton (-4%), dampening sentiment for UK stocks and the former leading to underperformance in the financial sector. Other individual movers include Hikma Pharmaceuticals (+9%) after appointing their new CEO, Fidessa (+21.4%) are also seen higher after reports that Swiss-listed Temenos (-6.8%) are to make an offer for the Co., while Intercontinental Hotels (-3.9%) have faced selling pressure this morning following a lacklustre earnings update.

FX

The DXY has now rebounded above 89.500, and on broad-based gains vs G10 rivals, albeit mainly inspired by another round of short covering. A major French bank notes that the market remains very short of Dollars (in line with latest weekly CFTC spec positioning data) and modestly long Jpy and moves in the headline pairing off last week’s circa 105.55 low support the rebalancing theory as spot trades back over 107.00. 107.32 offers eyed next, and as a recap this level now forms resistance rather than support on the way down as the 2017 low. Similar price moves elsewhere, as Eur/Usd recoils further from recent peaks and briefly testing bids at 1.2350 with small stops just below, but not challenging key Fib support at 1.2319. Cable briefly reclaimed the 1.4000 handle after reports in Business Insider suggested that the EU Parliament is to call for Britain to have privileged single market access after Brexit. Usd/Chf now inching closer to 0.9350 and Usd/Cad just shy of 1.2600 amidst the ongoing Greenback recovery, while Aud/Usd is retesting 0.7900 on the downside with little direction gleaned from RBA minutes overnight, but key data to come tomorrow (wage growth). Nzd/Usd straddling 0.7350, with strong chart support around 0.7338.

FIXED INCOME

A rather mixed 2 year German Schatz reception has not really deflected core bonds from what seems like an asset-related recovery as stocks retreat from earlier highs. Indeed, Bunds and Gilts remain close to fresh, albeit marginal intraday peaks at 158.29 and 121.07 respectively (+2 ticks and -6 ticks) and EZ peripheral paper is now all above parity as books for Spain’s 2048 issuance continues to swell. Not much traction being gleaned by US Treasuries that still have a mountain of supply to absorb, although futures are off worst levels and yields have eased a shade.

COMMODITIES

In the commodities complex, WTI and Brent crude futures are seen higher albeit off best levels as the firmer USD caps gains; WTI holds above the USD 62.00bbl level (note the weekly API inventories will be released tomorrow, not today due to yesterday’s US market holiday). In terms of energy news flow, the Joint OPEC/non-OPEC Technical Committee concluded that the oil glut is dissipating at a faster pace than anticipated, according to sources. Additionally, UAE energy minister claims OPEC and allies are to continue oil cooperation beyond 2018 and notes UAE, Saudi Arabia and Russia all support an extension cut beyond 2018. In metals markets, spot gold trades lower alongside the aforementioned firmer USD while copper prices have seen little in the way of firm direction as Chinese participants remain away from market.

UAE Energy Minister says the UAE is expected to over-deliver on production cuts in Q1 due to maintenance commitment with OPEC-led pact. (Newswires)

The DXY has now rebounded above 89.500, and on broad-based gains vs G10 rivals, albeit mainly inspired by another round of short covering. A major French bank notes that the market remains very short of Dollars (in line with latest weekly CFTC spec positioning data) and modestly long Jpy, and moves in the headline pairing off last week’s circa 105.55 low support the rebalancing theory as spot trades back over 107.00. 107.32 offers eyed next, and as a recap this level now forms resistance rather than support on the way down as the 2017 low. However, the partial recovery appears to be little more than consolidation at this stage and the real litmus test will come as auction results roll in. As usual, strong demand for syndicated paper as books swell to over Eur22.5 bn for Spain’s 2048 offering, albeit with a bigger premium and yield concession – note, Bono futures outperforming and just above parity in contrast to Eurozone peers. In metals markets, spot gold trades lower alongside the aforementioned firmer USD while copper prices have seen little in the way of firm direction as Chinese participants remain away from market.

subject: Barclays on today’s Schatz auction
content: Germany auctions EUR 5bln of a new March 20 ‘Schatz this morning. In outright terms, 2y yields in Germany stand about 22bps above the December lows and just 3bps from the highs touched briefly at the end of January. In cross-market terms, the front end of Germany has not moved much in recent weeks versus other core issuers. Nonetheless, current yield give-ups in Germany remain just a few basis points from their six-month lows. There is also a EUR 17bln bond redemption on Friday forthcoming.

ING: EGB supply
content:
Today Germany will launch a new 2yr Schatz for a target of €5bn. We see the roll for the BKO 3/20 at around 4bp. 2yr Germany has cheapened around 15bp on ASW since early December, and also versus other core EGBs a concession has built since then, so we expect the auction to go well. We especially like the new Schatz in a 2s30s ASW box, as we believe the short end is less vulnerable to ASW underperformance in the face of the upcoming end of net ECB QE.

Elsewhere, Spain is likely to come to the market to launch a new 30yr benchmark, as announced yesterday.

Tonight the Tesoro will publish the details of Friday’s CTZ and linker auction.

content: A relatively resilient start for 3 month UK STIR futures, with losses contained to 1-2 ticks despite US counterparts extending their declines to as much as 6.5 ticks. However, Gilts look all set for a more pronounced corrective markdown and retreat through 121.00 vs yesterday’s 121.13 settlement price as Bunds dip below 158.00 to a 157.96 Eurex low (-31 ticks on the day). Bonds and short term rates are back in bear territory and decoupling from stocks as more hawkish CB policy impulses and the sheer weight of US debt supply dampen sentiment. In terms of independent UK drivers, the CBI’s latest trends survey is expected to show a slowdown in headline orders, but this is not normally a major market-mover.

subject: DAILY BOND AUCTION PREVIEW: Supply today comes from Germany and the US
content:
AUCTION PREVIEW: ECB 7-Day MRO

Previously the ECB allotted EUR 1.32bln in its 7-day operation.

AUCTION PREVIEW: German EUR 5bln 0% 2020 Schatz Auction

IFR:

- European bonds sell off from prior Schatz auction January 23

- Schatz outperform in defensive trading amid general bear steepening

- Room for Schatz to continue to outperform on curve assuming further bear steepening

- Schatz underperform DSLs, significantly outperform Gilts and Treasuries

- Room for Schatz to continue to outperform against Gilts/Tsys

- Roll on new 3/20 Schatz talked around +5bp, about fair value

- Mixed recent history for Schatz auctions; Jan tap a technical failure

In terms of historical data: prev. b/c 1.07, average yield -0.61% and retention 19.4%

Bids are submitted by 1030GMT and results are submitted shortly after.

AUCTION PREVIEW: US to sell USD 28bln 2-year notes at 1800 GMT (1300 ET)

The US Treasury is to sell a total of USD 92bln in 2- (USD 28bln), 5- (USD 35bln) and 7-year (USD 29bln) notes this week, as well as hold a USD 15bln 2-year FRN auction. Next week sees approximately USD 107bln of cash flows which includes around USD 100bln in redemptions.

This set of auctions marks the first of 2-, 5- and 7-year auctions since the US Treasury announced they would be increasing the amount offered in January to help fund the anticipated growth in borrowing stemming from the Trump administration’s tax reform and spending package.

Last week, the 10-year yield hit its highest level in 4 years while 2-year yields hit their highest in over 9 years and some have suggested that the higher yields could see strong demand for the auctions.

“While the rise in yields could draw additional demand, investors have remained very picky on where they decide to buy front-end rates,” writes TD Securities. “We therefore look for relatively cautious demand at this week’s auction series.”

Chinese participation is also likely to be of interest (although we won’t find out foreign participation immediately). A recent article suggested that Chinese officials had recommended slowing or halting purchases of US Treasuries but data since the article hasn’t

subject: Bunds: inching back down towards 158.00 psychological support
content: Another gap down in the 10 year German debt future in line with the increasingly bearish tone in core bonds, and especially US Treasuries ahead of very heavy short and longer dated issuance. Indeed, the 2 year T-note yield has ramped up again to just shy of 2.23% and its highest level since September 2008 in the run up to supply comprising some Usd156 bn bills and Usd28 bn 2 year paper later today. The Eurex range so far has been 158.08-20 vs Monday’s 158.27 close, and bears/sellers will be eyeing the nearest big figure for obvious reasons on a further downturn. Ahead, ZEW provides the main macro highlight after firmer than expected German PPI data in y/y terms. Back to supply, Germany launches a new Schatz benchmark as the cash yield continues to trade around -0.5%.

subject: DAILY EUROPEAN OPENING NEWS: Asian equities are seen lower with the Nikkei 225 (-1.1%) the laggard after tripping stops through 22,000 to the downside
content:
• Asian equities are seen lower with the Nikkei 225 (-1.1%) the laggard after tripping stops through 22,000 to the downside
  • Reports suggest the UK could be willing to withhold their Brexit settlement bill. Netherlands prepares for a hard Brexit
  • Looking ahead, highlights include German ZEW, German and US supply

ASIA

Equity markets are somewhat fragile, with major Asian bourses off to a weaker start. US markets were closed for President’s day and as such, Asian participants took the cue from European equities which slipped in yesterday’s session. In Australia, the ASX 200 (-0.4%) has come under pressure from material and financial names, with many of the large banks reversing the prior days gains. Over in Japan, the Nikkei (-1.3%) had tripped through 22,000 amid softness in tech names. The Hang Seng (-0.3%) reopened for the first time since last week, however initial gains had been short-lived, with the index conforming to the sombre tone.

JGBs are flat in thin-trade, March futures contract down 2 ticks and hovering near yesterday’s levels. USTs off by 6+ ticks with yields continuing to pick up, 2yr yields now at the highest since Sep’08 after hitting 2.22%, while the US curve is also flattening this morning.

UK/EU

Spain’s Economy Minister de Guindos was confirmed as the nominee by the Eurogroup for the ECB Vice-President role. (Newswires)

ECB's Hansson (hawk) says he's not interested in becoming ECB President. (Newswires)

The UK is said to have a secret plan to withhold Brexit payments if the EU refuses to provide the UK with a desirable trade deal. (Newswires) Elsewhere, according to a letter seen last week, Netherlands government has linked its decision to activate hard Brexit plan amid a lack of clarity from the UK. (Sky)
 

FX

The RBA meeting minutes failed to provide any fireworks with the central bank sticking with its neutral tone. As such, AUD had been largely unmoved post the release of the minutes and instead focus will fall on the wage price index due out tomorrow. AUD briefly dipped below 0.79 amid the push higher in the USD index, while AUD/NZD ran into resistance at 1.0750. Elsewhere, a leg lower in equity markets, provided support for the JPY with major cross falling to intra-day lows, with the exception of the USD/JPY which has benefited from some short-covering. NZD will be in focus later today with participants awaiting the latest Fonterra GDT auction. According to CBA, WMP futures are suggesting that prices will be flat.

In the EM space, PHP had outperformed against the greenback after comments from the Philippine Central Bank chief, who stated that the BSP will not hesitate to raise rates if inflation risks persist. KRW fell amid rising fears of American protectionist policy’s (namely proposal to impose hefty steel tariffs), which has prompted South Korea to threaten that a retaliation is possible.

RBA February minutes states that low rates are helping reduce unemployment and lift inflation, additionally rising AUD would impede pick up in economic growth and inflation, however AUD TWI is still within narrow range of past couple of years. (Newswires)


COMMODITIES

Brent and WTI crude futures traded with modest gains overnight, however did pull off best levels amid the slip in risk sentiment. Declines in WTI came to a halt after meeting support at USD 62.00/bbl. Precious metals are slightly softer as USD consolidates above 89.00.

Libya's NOC says budget delays may negatively impact oil production. (Newswires)


US

US markets were closed for a public holiday.
